name: Great Fosters

reviews.text: I recently booked an event at The Great Fosters. The conference facilities were second to none, very modern and catered for all our needs, whereas the hotel bedrooms are like stepping back in time (in a good way). Very oldy worldy and each room special in its' own right. The food and the service was the best i remember in a hotel in a long time.....very attentive without being too overbearing. All in all a fantastic few days and would definitely recommend.
reviews.title: Fantastic in all areas

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at Great Fosters for 1 night having booked through Small Luxury Hotels. We were upgraded to a Cloisters Suite with a glass of champagne on arrival and a welcome gift. The hotel is truly outstanding. The welcome we received on reception from Darren was excellent, very friendly and professional. After being shown to our room we explored the hotel. I have to say it was immaculate in every way. Spotlessly clean and in very very good condition. The modern & contemporary cloisters suites work very the history of the Grand building itself. The gardens obviously receive a great deal of attention, there is not a leaf our of place.
reviews.title: Fantastic Hotel, with Outstanding service

reviews.text: I have visited three times since I last reviewed Great Fosters back in January but have not got around to reviewing so will do all 3 visits in one fell swoop! Not difficult as couldn't fault it in any way. In fact I get a warm fuzzy feeling whenever I think of Great Fosters as my memories of it are so happy, always with family, always a wonderful experience. Came in June with my son who is at Royal Holloway, had the most beautiful meal sitting outside overlooking the water and all the blossoms were out. Then came again in July to the Taste of Summer day with my eldest son as a 21st birthday treat for him. First time I had been to one of their events and it was magical, despite the unpredictability of the weather and my son loved it too. The sun came out eventually and we got to swim in the pool which I had always yearned to do, and tickle the piglets!! The whole day was so special for both of us, all the staff were so wonderful. The third visit was last week for lunch when my sister was over from France and again, the food and service were superb. As to the comments I made in my previous review about the portion sizes, that appears to have been addressed, portion sizes have been fine on every visit since. I am so looking forward to the Christmas event which was recommended to me by people I met at the Taste of Summer day, I can't imagine a place that would be more festive and I am bringing my friends along this time. Well done to all the staff at Great Fosters, who really do justice to this truly remarkable place . Can't wait to return!
reviews.title: Totally enchanted!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed for one evening, Sat 20th October. We were attending a friends wedding in London and they had their wedding reception at the hotel. The staff were brilliant, nothing was to much for them. From the purchase of a couple of good cigars to the food and wine selection, everything was superb. The hotel is easy to find, it has beutiful gardens. The interior is fantastic. The only negative was that we couldnt stay a while longer!!!
reviews.title: Fabulous Stay.

reviews.text: Not sure how I stumbled across this English gem on the Internet, but it was truly more than I expected - so much more! Last night in England and Heathrow was only 7 miles away. Yet it felt like an enormous step back in time. Originally "built as a hunting lodge in 1550", it could very easily pass for something off a movie set. Our very clean, well furnished contemporary room, the "Barouche #335, located in one of the renovated "wings", was very spacious and well equipped with amenities you would expect for the level of luxury. (As a side note, the room's windows opened, which is no big deal, but they appeared to be leaded glass panes with very simple wrought iron frames and latch, and they weren't "double-glazed".) The room had a very comfortable queen size bed, where as our single friend's room, the "Hansom", had a full size bed in an unexpectedly cramped area - she would have gladly paid the difference for a double. We did not eat dinner in their restaurant, but did experience their breakfast. Seek it on the Net if you want an out of the ordinary (pinch me, I must be dreaming) experience.
reviews.title: Excellent!

reviews.title: Luxurious & cosy

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: On our first night me, the bride, two other bridesmaids and a bridesman stayed in the Tapestry Room. This is easily the biggest hotel room I have ever seen, let alone stayed in. I don't think my flat is small but this room was about the consolidated size of it. The staff were absolutely on-point and had no trouble at adding three camp beds to accommodate us all. There was more than enough space for all five of us and the bathroom was very convenient: one main room with hand-basins and roll-top bath with seperate shower room and toilet of it. This was most convenient when we were all readying ourselves for the wedding the next day as several things could go on at once without us getting on top of each other.
reviews.title: Amazing!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We made use of the complimentary hospitality tray (as some rooms don't come with tea/coffee making facilities but the hotel is more than happy to supply these if required) and ordered room service which arrived quickly and was delicious. Add the Molton Brown miniature toiletries and it was a pretty blissful night.
reviews.title: Best anniversary yet!

reviews.text: We took breakfast the next day in the Oak Room restaurant (after an early-morning wonder round the grounds which is a must) and while it is not an 'all-you-can-eat', over-flowing continental buffet selection it was nonetheless tasty and very filling. The staff were then exceptional in assisting the bride with the last preparations and there were at least two people on hand at any one time making sure the wedding party was where we needed to be. Their organisation was faultless and the wedding breakfast and reception afterwards was wonderful. Highly recommended as a wedding venue.
reviews.title: A Real Treat

reviews.text: For the second night me and my husband stayed in the Waterloo Room which was simply lovely. The room consisted of three seperate areas, one a bedroom with bed (obviously), armchairs, TV etc., a small dressing area with a wardrobe and table and chair with mirror, and a spacious bathroom. The rate was £175 for the night including breakfast which I feel is enough to pay but with complimentary water, slippers and robes, it really was luxurious.
reviews.title: Afternoon tea delight

description: Probably built as a Royal Hunting lodge and very much a stately home since the 16th century, Great Fosters is now a prestigious hotel. Set amongst 50 acres of gardens and parkland, the hotel is a Grade One listed building blessed with the grandeur of 16th century England and luxurious modern facilities. Its past is evident in the mullioned windows, tall chimneys, fireplaces and brick finials, while the Saxon moat, crossed by a Japanese bridge, surrounds three sides of the formal garden. All the suites and bedrooms are individually decorated. The bedrooms in the Main House are adorned with tapestries and antiques, whilst the bedrooms in The Cloisters are more contemporary in style. The Coach House, refurbished in 2008, offers luxurious accommodation with the latest plasma screens, i-pod docking stations and fabulous bathrooms. The hotel offers a choice of two restaurants, The Estate Grill and The Tudor Room at Great Fosters. The Estate Grill is less formal and serves a simple and seasonal menu with many of the dishes cooked on a Josper grill. The Tudor Room at Great Fosters is an intimate, more sophisticated dining experience with just 24 covers set in a lavishly decorated dining room.
